Materials.Name: Precipitation-Hardening Stainless Steels, Armco 17-4PH
Materials.References: Reactor Handbook, Vol. 1: composition from Table 23.50 and density from Table 23.52.  Average of the range was used for Cr, Ni and Al. Impurities taken at their maximum values.  Balance is iron.  Density is 7.78 g/cm3 as annealed at 1900F; density of 7.80 g/cm3 as aged at 900F for 1 hr.

Materials.Name: Precipitation-Hardening Stainless Steels, Armco 17-7PH
Materials.References: Reactor Handbook, Vol. 1: composition from Table 23.50 and density from Table 23.51.  Average of the range was used for Cr, Ni and Al. Impurities taken at their maximum values.  Balance is iron.  Density is 7.81 g/cm3 for annealing at 1950F and air cooling; density is 7.65 g/cm3 for annealing at 1950F, treated at 1400F and aged at 950F or 1050F.

Materials.Name: Precipitation-Hardening Stainless Steels, USS Stainless W
Materials.References: Reactor Handbook, Vol. 1: composition from Table 23.50 and density from Table 23.53.  Average of the range was used for Cr, Ni and Al. Impurities taken at their maximum values.  Balance is iron.  Density of 7.65 g/cm3 is listed for both annealed and aged.

Materials.Name: Pure dry air
Materials.References: Reactor Handbook, Vol. 1: composition from Table 48.1. Figure 48.1 lists a gas constant for air of 0.3705 (psia ft3)/(lb R).  At STP (491.67 R, 14.6959 psia), the ideal gas law gives a density of 0.08067 lb/ft3 (0.001292 g/cm3).  Table 51.14 lists a density of air of 0.001294 g/cm3.

Chapter 37 Boron by W. K. Anderson
